ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Enlarged Vestibular Aqueducts (EVA)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by historical imaging (CT/MRI) at age 4; clinical presentation of progressive, stepwise sensorineural hearing loss in childhood is characteristic.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometric findings show bone conduction thresholds consistent with air conduction thresholds, indicating sensorineural pathology.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess current hearing thresholds and speech recognition abilities given the history of progression.
Indicated for the left ear due to poor speech recognition (16%) and severity of hearing loss.
Previously performed at age 4, confirming the diagnosis of Enlarged Vestibular Aqueducts.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient demonstrates asymmetric bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (Right: mild-severe, Left: moderate-profound). Middle ear function is normal. Speech understanding is excellent in the right ear but very poor in the left ear, suggesting limited benefit from conventional amplification on the left.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear pressure and mobility.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflexes
tests.result_summary: Reflexes present when stimulating the Right ear (Ipsi and Contra) but absent when stimulating the Left ear, consistent with severe left-sided afferent deficit.

tests.name: Pure-tone Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Mild low/mid-frequency SNHL sloping to severe. Left ear: Moderate-to-severe sloping to profound SNHL.

tests.name: Speech Audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 25 dB with 100% WRS; Left SRT 65 dB with 16% WRS.

tests.name: Wideband Reflectance
tests.result_summary: Patterns consistent with normal middle ear status.

proposed_items: Fit and verify a BTE hearing aid for the Right ear.
Refer for Cochlear Implant (CI) evaluation for the Left ear.
Implement FM/DM system for classroom use.
counseling_actions: Counsel on the progressive nature of hearing loss associated with EVA.
Strongly advise against contact sports and activities with risk of head trauma to preserve residual hearing.
Discuss the disparity in speech clarity between ears and the potential benefits of CI for the left ear.

red_flags_present: Progressive hearing loss in a pediatric patient.
Disproportionately poor speech recognition in the Left ear (16%).

escalation.rationale_short: The left ear's speech recognition score is 16%, indicating that a hearing aid is providing insufficient benefit and a cochlear implant should be considered.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds for further progression, check hearing aid function, and track CI evaluation status.

expected_outcome: Optimized audibility in the Right ear with amplification.
Potential restoration of functional hearing in the Left ear via Cochlear Implantation.
Prevention of sudden hearing drops through trauma avoidance.
